bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean and Albert E. Truby, February 20, 1941

div1.p: Hench explains the painting of Walter Reed proposed by the John Wyeth Company. He criticizes the dominant role of Finlay in their preliminary sketches and offers suggestions to improve upon the scene.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean and Albert E. Truby, February 20, 1941

opener.salute: My dear Generals Kean and Truby:

div1.p:
Permit me to send you each this same letter, to save time and hasten
this letter along. I have just recovered from a nasty seige of the flu. The only
pleasant thing that happened while I was sick was that one day I received a wonder-
ful long letter from General Kean and the next day the grand letter of General
Truby. I cannot today answer these letters, but will only say how grateful I am
for them.

Permit me to write you about another but related matter, of which General
Kean knows something but you, General Truby, do not. The John Wyeth Co., an old and
reputable pharmaceutical house in Philadelphia, has begun a series of fine paintings
on medical subjects, painted by a nationally known artist. Two have already appeared,
one on Dr. Beaumont and one on Dr. Osler; thousands of colored reproductions of each
have been disseminated throughout the country to physicians and the original paintings
are being exhibited in various medical institutions. Of course this is a form of
advertising but it is the highest type of advertising. Already the two paintings
have been copied in books and the Beaumont painting was copied in the magazine TIME
two weeks ago. In other words, these paintings may probably serve as classical re-
presentation of their subjects for some time to come. When I heard that they planned
to do one on Walter Reed, I wrote the company hoping that I might procure the origin-
al or an oil copy of the original, or at least a fine colored reproduction, to hang
in the small museum in Havana which I hope to see built in memory of Camp Lazear.
When Mr. George Kellogg of the Wyeth Co. learned of my interest, to my surprise he
wired that he and an associate were coming the whole way out to see me as they were
interviewing various men who might help them make these paintings historically
accurate. In their desire to accomplish the latter they had spent some days in Cuba,
where they had fallen under the spell of Mrs. Finlay, Albertini and others and had
decided to give Dr. Finlay, Sr. a dominant role in the painting. I spent many hours
trying to give them a correct version of the conquest of yellow fever, with the re-
sult that I believe they plan to revise their painting entirely. The enclosed
snapshot of their preliminary sketches show Finlay in the dominating role with the
American physicians led by Reed who stands, hat in hand, listening to the oracular
words of the great Cuban sage. In the one picture Lazear's role is so minimized
that he almost didn't get in the door. I did not believe that the American medical
profession would accept this version kindly. You, General Kean, have already seen
these pictures. What is your candid opinion?

I took the privilege of telling them that you, General Truby, had informa-
tion in addition to that of General Kean. I told them of your dramatic three or
four pages from your diary in which you described Lazear's death, the discovery of
the little notebook and the eagerness with which Dr. Reed studied this notebook.
Mr. Kellogg is most anxious to obtain further information from you both and I believe
will write to you further. I told them that my idea of such a painting would be to
portray Lazear inoculating Carroll with the other members of the commission, and also
Finlay looking on. When this happened of course Reed was actually in Washington
and Finlay was probably not on the scene but certainly artistic license would permit
Reed and Finlay to be put in this painting by all means. The portrayal of any
later scene would necessitate the absence of Dr. Lazear, which would seem unfair.
The inoculation probably took place within Dr. Reed's little laboratory. Mr. Kellogg
was afraid that the interior of a small wooden laboratory would not be interesting
enough to satisfy the artist. As an alternative, it was suggested that the scene
be portrayed on the veranda of the officers' porch where so many of their conferences
took place. I have written you, General Truby, telling you of my continued vain
search for photographs of the officers' quarters. After two years of searching I
have found a fairly good photograph of it in one of the reports of the Governor
General of Cuba. Is this similar to the one you have? I showed it to them, and
also identified the general location of Reed's little laboratory, and showed them
a photograph of the model of Camp Columbia. They now write me that Mr. Cornwell,
the artist, much prefers to protray the scene just in front of the officers' quarters
with the latter in the immediate background and perhaps with Kissinger and Moran
sitting or standing on the steps--all of this for the sake of proper lighting of the
scene in the painting. This is a technical point I can't quite understand but the
important point is to know whether you feel that this is taking entirely too much
license from historical accuracy. In such a scene the drabness would be relieved by
some palm trees and Cuban foliage.

The Wyeth people have gone to great extremes to insure accuracy and detail.
They are anxious to know the nature of the boarding of the officers' quarters, the
color of its paint, and the nature of the uniforms worn by those involved. I loaned
them a photograph of the hospital corps on the steps of the ward. This shows a
variety of uniforms, yours, General Truby, probably represents that of a regular
medical officer and differs from that of Drs. Pinto and Amador who as contract
surgeons apparently were a different uniform. I was puzzled by the uniform of Dr.
Cooke, which seems to be like that of Dr. Pinto except for the shoulder straps which
resemble that of Dr. Truby.

I am sure that both of you will wish to see an honest portrayal of the
scene, and as long as such a painting is going to be made and so widely exhibited I
felt that those of us who are no interested in the story should be as helpful as
possible. I shall be most interested in your reaction to this proposition and I
shall bavvery glad to receive carbons of such letters as you may write to Mr. Kellogg
and deem it proper for me to see.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
P. S. I forgot to mention that my suggestion was to have the scene
portray Carroll with his shirt sleeve rolled up and Lazear placing the test tube con-
taining the mosquito on Carroll's forearm. This action would be the focal point of
the scene. Major Reed would be presumably looking on most earnestly and occupying
a prominent position, Drs. Agramonte and Finlay would be included in appropriate
poses. It was suggested that two or three additional figures occupying less prominent
roles would fill out and relieve the scene. If there were to be other figures I suggested
that Kissinger and Moran be given the compliment of being included as representative of
the enlisted men. Would they be sitting down in the presence of their superior officers?
Could they accurately be portrayed as standing in the background looking on? To relieve
the monotony of several male figures it was suggested that a woman's figure be included,
that of an army nurse, and the idea was to have Miss Maas in the scene even though her
work didn't come until later. Was she around there at the time?
